subject: Re: [junit] testing abstract methods
msgSnippet: In your test you can create a concrete subclass of the abstract class that has implementations of the abstract methods that do whatever is appropriate for the
messageBody:
In your test you can create a concrete subclass of the abstract class that
has implementations of the abstract methods that do whatever is appropriate
for the tests.

However, I would only test the subclasses. The abstract base class is just
an implementation detail of the subclasses. It is the behaviour of
instantiable objects that is important to the rest of the system. Whether
some of that behaviour is in a baseclass or not is not important.

--Nat

On 04/01/2008, Chandima R <choi_chandima@...> wrote:
>
> hi Kumar
>
> I'm trying to test non abstract methods in an abstract class which has
> been inherited by child classes.but i need not to test abstract parent
> class via creating child class instances. Is there any way to achieve this
> using junit. please instruct me.
> thanks..
> chandima
>
> ----- Original Message ----

> >
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com <junit%40yahoogroups.com>
> Sent: Friday, January 4, 2008 4:24:59 AM
> Subject: Re: [junit] testing abstract methods
>
> Hi Chandima,
>
> I m not getting your question properly...
>
> Do you want to test abstract class or abstract methods ???
>
> abstract methods cannot be tested as there is no logic written in them.
> But you can test non abstract methods of abstract class.
>
> Good Luk
